comments.author: lars dood

comments.text:
+RawrSaysOlivia
 Man I'm sorry to burst your bubble but I used to study at a Korean 
university (Seoul National) and lived in Seoul and Korean people are 
completely aware that K-pop and drama are fantasies, to a much larger 
degree than foreigners. In fact, many people are aware that a lot of 
westerners idolize Korean society because of music videos etc and some few 
exploit it. In the night district of both Gangnam and Hongdae I've run into 
boy groups of really sweet-looking, handsome Korean guys that have 
specialized in seducing foreign girls who come to Korea because of their 
love for K-pop and dramas, and will act sweet and impersonate people from 
dramas in order to seduce them. Then, once they get to sleep with you, 
they'll dump you and add you to their list (and high-five their pals and 
brag about it to the foreign guys they meet in the bars ("oh, you're from x 
country? I slept with a girl from there y weeks ago!")). Furthermore, as 
Korean pop and dramas are an expression of, the pressure for good looks is 
EXTREME in South Korea and there are certain areas of Seoul (esp around 
Insa-dong) that are just CLUSTERED with plastic surgery clinics. The subway 
stations too have all kinds of advertisements for plastic surgery, and 
people who are considered unattractive in Korean society are regularily 
harassed for this. Examples I've encountered are 1. meeting a group of 
friends of a friend and them apologizing that the girls who are there are 
ugly, while they stare embarrased into the table and 2. hearing my foreign 
friend get told she's "too fat to get a boyfriend" constantly when she 
expresses that she wants to meet someone. In other words, if you're 
unattractive don't expect Korean guys to be sweet. They'll probably tell 
you directly to your face that you're not.

Now Koreans are a lot of fun and are cool to be with (their frankness is at 
first very intimidating but they make for excellent close friends), and 
Seoul is a magnificent city if you go there with the right mindset. But 
idolizing Korean society and Korean guys because of what you see in music 
videos and dramas is a dangerous way to think cause it makes you a) look 
down on your own local guys who might not be that bad at all once you look 
past certain flaws that you think Koreans don't have because b) you think 
Koreans are perfect beings and are unable to see flaws in their characters 
as well. Koreans are just people too, and the chances are if you're coming 
to Korea you'll find a lot of Korean guys are more interested in Korean 
girls or PC Bang, and if they are interested in you then there's quite a 
chance they're playboys looking for their next target. I've studied at a 
Japanese university too, and I must say it's comparable to the western guys 
coming to Japan because of the Japanese adult videos they've watched that 
have given them unrealistic expectations of what Japanese girls are like. 
I've met some white guys in Tokyo who think it's realistic they'll get to 
have sex with schoolgirls in public toilet because they're white and 
Japanese girls what to do it with foreigners anywhere, anytime. say whaaat

Not to shit talk Korea, though, cause it'll have a heart in my place 
forever as one of the countries I lived in for an extended period of time 
(a bit more than 1 year). But going to Seoul knowing that it's a HUGE 
metropolitan with both good and bad sides that has a lot to offer in 
entertainment and culture is a much better mindset than thinking it's a 
fairytale-city where guys will give you teddy bears and roses in the hope 
of getting to kiss your cheek. That's a fantasy. It's not going to happen.
comments.author: lars dood
